reviewText:
One night I was sitting in my chat room and got a message from a friend.. He said: Wany!! there is this new developer made his first new game! Try it out!!" I was like.. what the heck... any games that increase my game collection count would be fine! So I did just that.

One week later the review count for this game was still kinda low but the rating of the game stayed 90% postive after 32 people reviewed...

Well.. I better play and try this...

First impression.. What is this!!.. you are a white dot travel in black space and shoot black dots hidden in shadow? At least music is great!!

Second impression.. Hmm this is a bit harder then i throught.. Being a TouHou veteren it's nothing that i couldn't handle...

Third impression ...Wow.. speed is increasing.. and enemy is going getting more massive... Hmm beat all boss achievements already? Well.. at least it's still keep getting harder....

Fourth impression.. okkiee.. this is getting much more insane and crazy to stay alive... Darn it I died and lost all my power.. Darn it again.. IT's like impossible to recover at this stage without my power.. And I am dead again!! And Again!! Grr... Last life!.. Bosss? no.. Dead...

Thus end my first try at this game..
Rank 28 on Normal .. beats all my friends that tried this.. CatzZz rank 45
date:
dkny rank 182.... Cool...

Since I unlocked a few new weapon.. Let's try this again!!!

Simple Indie Game and i would call it great success!! Keep up the great work!

8.5/10 Recommend for everyone to try.. and Beat my score my friends!"

reviewText:
Shmadow is a fun little twin-stick shmup game with tough bosses and power-ups to help you through the game. One of the special things about this game is that it features 4 player LOCAL co-op(Xbox and Playstation controller fully supported and required for co-op), something that is not often done in video games these days. You can play this game with your buddys on the coach while drinking root beer and eating Oreo's.

But on to the actual substance of the game.
You are a ball of light navigating through the dark with the help of your bullets to light the way and destroy all that goes against you (which is pretty much everything on the screen except for the background). You can get power ups after defeating bosses you encounter. These bosses can be very brutal, from slowing down and speeding up time, to bombarding you with lazers and drowning you with bullets. All while trying to avoid or destroy black blobs that damages/kills you opon touch.

There are three difficulties: Casual, Normal and Nightmare. These names don't lie. Casual is fairly easy with some practice, Normal is what you would expect and Nightmare is for those who enjoy getting pwned (I know I still say pwn, I'm stuck in 2007). The game also features a leaderboard for each difficulty.

And the music in this game is fairly decent. Goes well with the game.

For the core price of 2$, I personally think this game is worth a checkout.

reviewText: Shrinking dot in darkness"Does shmadow mean "mad shadow"? However this game is a simplistic space shooter and bullet hell. You fly through dark space and only your shots can light it up. date: rotating lasers or bubble spaceworms. One is changing gravity so that all background bubbles come from one side. Tho the game is flat 2D and the powerups are not very useful or there isn't even a decent tutorial the game makes fun for a short while. If you get hit your dot shrinks down to a minimum dot. A nice game mechanic. Achievements just count from normal difficulty up to nightmare. Local coop included
recommended: steam leaderboards and a techno loop soundtrack. Nothing special but quite enjoyable."

reviewText:
If I had to describe Shmadow in a few words I'd have to say it's as if bullet hells, endless runners, and sidescrollers had a child. There isn't very much to say about this game but let's talk about it anyway. You're a ball of light who shoots other balls of various colors. Your character and your bullets produce light allowing you to see through the darkness. The more damage you take the less light you produce making it harder to survive. You get get an attack that recharges over a short cooldown and you pickup powerups which can also be used to assist you. You fight bosses and your objective is to make it as far as you can without losing. That's pretty much all there is to say about Shmadow.

The Good
One of the easiest achievement hunts you'll ever see.
You can play through the entire game and refund it if you don't enjoy it due to the game being so short.
You don't need a controller to do well (I got every achievement using keyboard and mouse).
Due to trading cards existing you'll make a large portion of what you spent on the game (if you bought it on sale) back from selling them.
Very short soundtrack although it's a very fitting song that doesn't get annoying.
Regardless of how much playtime you get it's still only 2 USD.
Several difficulties/modes.
Really cool bosses.
The Bad
Super short playtime (15 ish minutes if you're playing normally and 30-90 minutes if you're achievement hunting depending on how good you are at Shmadow). One playthrough of the game is enough for a player to see every boss along with the majority of the content.
I like the graphics although I cannot deny that there was very little effort put into them.
There's no tutorial although there's a controls section on the main menu.
You have to use the powerup to know what it does (they have no titles, just icons) and for a game this short I doubt you want to memorize all of them.
If you're poor (and I mean very poor) this game isn't a good choice for you considering the lack of playtime you'll get out of it. If you aren't poor you've got nothing to lose no matter how much playtime you get out of it.

reviewText: Shmadow is a shmup where a flying death flashlight shoots glowy light bullets at a never ending asteroid field of darkness.  Every now and then, you encounter other orbs of light - dark, sinister glowing red suns that shoot scarlet death lazers at you, and command the shadow asteroids to swarm your light ship like spherical ninja zombies.\nIt's clever, it's tricky, and its' simple premise lends itself well to short play sessions.\nPlus, Shmadow is just fun to say. Shmadow. Shma-dough. Shh-mad-ow. SCHMA-doh. So good.

reviewText:
This game has taught me how bad I am at twin stick bullet hell shooters.

If you're into this sort of title, I'd recommend checking it out.

There are several unique enemies and bosses, at least that I've encountered so far, which are presented in a such a way that you can tell how they work relatively quickly without having to die to them 10 times.  The graphic styling and music combine to create a sense of environment while maintaining the hectic pace of a true bullet-hell.  My favorite part of this release though is the global scoreboard allowing you to tell just how poorly you measure up against other players and then of course, that music!

Cool first release from Extrokold, looking forward to seeing what comes in the future and will enjoy this one from time to time when I need to blast things for a few minutes.

reviewText:
Quick Breakdown: A twin stick shooter, wherein you play as a ball of light, fending for oneself amidst the darkness.
Length:  15+ minutes
Genre: Arcade / Twin Stick Shooter
Score: 5/10

Full Review: Thereâ€™s not a whole lot to this game; you play as a ball of light in a world of shadows, except for the background, everything in the world is dark. You illuminate your surroundings with your bullets and with the ball of light that serves essentially as your vessel. Plenty of random blobs of darkness hurtle toward you like asteroids, and will darken, and even blackout the area until destroyed or passed. Occasionally you face bosses, whom will drop various power-ups.

Thatâ€™s really all there is to the game, and thatâ€™s the trouble with it; I want to like this game, but thereâ€™s just not enough to it. The shadow gimmick remind me a bit of Limbo  (though the art isnâ€™t nearly to that caliber), and itâ€™s kinda a neat one, but thereâ€™s very little to the gameplay. Thereâ€™s no levels, or end boss, you just play for a high score; and while thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing (both the original Geometry Wars and Waves are twin stick shooters that do just that), the gameplay isnâ€™t gripping enough to compel me to aim for a high score. The levels and enemies are randomized, so that at least helps mix up the gameplay a bit, but itâ€™s still not enough.

I want to be able to recommend this game, but I canâ€™t. After playing it for a mere 15 minutes, Iâ€™m probably not ever going to touch this one again. Itâ€™s not bad per se, so much as itâ€™s not enough. Still, I only paid $0.50 for it, so itâ€™s not like my wallet is hurting from it. But if you need a twin stick shooter, youâ€™re better off buying Geometry Wars 3 instead. Itâ€™ll cost you a bit more than this game, but itâ€™s well worth it.

reviewText:
Shmadow is a nice idea that is poorly exicuted.  The dots of shadow that are randomly flying around would be fine if the area you could see was not limited.  The area of the screen that you can see them consists of a where you are shooting and an area around you that get smaller and smaller as you loose health.  The other enimies you can always see, but it is hard to deal with them when you cannot see your suroundings.

Another problem I had with this game is that the controlles did not feel right.  (Although it may just be me)  In a shmup game like this feel is every thing.  When the movement and shooting do not feel right it is hard to enjoy the game as a whole.  (I played with keyboard and mouse and with an xbox controller)

Although I do not recomend the game, I do like the music and I think it could be a great game.

Photoshop is a wonderful tool. Sure, with enough training and experience you can make ugly people look attractive and make all of the shame disappear with a few brush strokes. It's a powerful thing. But any random kid using it can make something way cooler. Photoshop is full of fun little tools that can make it look like you know what you're doing when you really don't. reviewText:
I don't get the postive reviews at all. This game is an exercise in torture: it's a simple mouse and keyboard shooter, but the majority of your enemies are little black dots that you can't actually see until they're half a pixel away from your character. This means that when you try and fight and dodge the real enemies you end up randomly dying. Combine that with your view radius getting smaller if you get hit means that it actually gets harder if you make a mistake.

Maybe I'm weird, but I don't want to play a game just to die from (virtually) invisible enemies every time it starts getting interesting.

Plus the soundtrack is terrible. Avoid, just avoid.

reviewText:
If you ask me, this game wants to be Touhou so bad. Though, no one's asking me, so whatev's. As another reviewer pointed out how s/he is a Touhou veteran and this game shouldn't be a problem... well, I'm a casual Touhou player and can't vouch for my own skills, but I could get through Lunatic fine on Touhou without dying a hundred times.

Anyone can make a difficult game, to be completely blunt about it. There's a lot missing from this game. The major thing is consistency. I feel like a shoot 'em up should have consistency. But in this case, it's all about points and not necessarily getting to level 10 or 20. Aspects of power ups and maybe variety? Not quite sure.

With all that negativity said and done, I will admit, I had a fair bit of fun. Honestly probably because of how great the music is.

Buy it if you can get it for like a dollar or less. Can't say it's worth more than that.

reviewText:
An interesting take on twin-stick shooters.
The addition of shadows makes the onslaight of enemies much less overwhelming for players new to the genre (such as myself).
boss battles are fun and memorable.
Only complaints I have are a) the game doesn't really tell you much and b) this might just be my controller, but charge attacks either don't work or don't work the way they should.

Go to Store (Featured), Click on Games, Narrow by Feature (Steam Trading Cards), Relevance (Lowest Price).

Add them to your Wishlist, games that are a dollar can go on sale and you may be able to purchase for cheap!
A game at .50 may give you that value back in trading cards.
Search and Install Idle Master" which will run your games even without the game being installed.
